I'll throw in a recipe for Varenyky.

Recipe for Potato Dumplings (Varenyky)
Ingredients:
For the dough:
Wheat flour – 500 g
Water – 200 ml
Egg – 1
Salt – 1 tsp
For the filling:
Potatoes – 1 kg
Onions – 2
Lard or butter – 50 g
Salt – to taste
Ground black pepper – to taste
Preparation steps:
Making the dough:
Sifting the flour: Sift the flour into a large bowl.
Making the dough: Add salt and the egg to the flour. Gradually pour in the water, constantly stirring. Knead the dough until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Resting the dough: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap or cover it with a towel and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Preparing the filling:
Boiling the potatoes: Peel the potatoes, cut them into large pieces, and boil until tender in salted water.
Preparing the onions: While the potatoes are boiling, finely chop the onions. Sauté the onions in lard or butter until golden brown.
Making the potato puree: Drain the potatoes and mash them. Add the sautéed onions, salt, and pepper to taste, and mix well.
Forming the dumplings:
Rolling out the dough: Roll out the dough into a thin sheet about 2-3 mm thick. Use a glass or cutter to cut out circles approximately 7-8 cm in diameter.
Forming the dumplings: Place a spoonful of potato filling on each circle of dough. Fold the dough in half and pinch the edges tightly to seal the dumplings.
Cooking the dumplings:
Boiling water: Bring a large pot of water to a boil, add salt.
Cooking the dumplings: Gently drop the dumplings into the boiling water, stirring carefully to prevent sticking. Cook until done (approximately 5-7 minutes after they float to the surface).
Serving:
Removing the dumplings: Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and place them on a plate.
Serving: Serve the dumplings hot, optionally drizzling with melted butter, sour cream, or sautéed onions.
Enjoy your meal!

The game has become incredibly grindy to the point of absolute and complete boredom, every step from crafting classes, items or furniture has become insanely bloated with meaningless resources and extra steps. 

The game supposedly has a botting problem, but it's the other way around, it has a gameplay problem. Grinding for that next piece of gear, mount, pet or cosmetic is fun when done in moderation, this whole game's identity has become the grind.

"looks like you're logging in from a new place" no. no I am not. eventually my account is "live". open game, seems fine BOOM the game is in some absurd resolution where i can see 1/10th of the corner of the opening screen, do some googling "you need to install blah blah blah" "if youre using nvidia do this" "amd super resolution must be turned off for this ONE SPECIFIC GAME" i gave up, uninstalled and requested to delete my account. AVOID ANY GAMIGO GAME LIKE THE PLAGUE HOLY SH*T

Poorly optimised game that if it actually loads correctly crashes... For me when the game starts (and that is not from clicking play from steam, nope you must have some launcher to separate it) it does not make it a central view, i.e. the game is almost tabbed out... Then the second issue is if it did launch, when I open it I'm stuck with a blue or white screen varying, I noticed that I can move zoom in and rotate the camera, not sure where the focus is the game is launched... Then when the game is playing I get random screen tearing and see glitches, almost like it is running something in the background hmm... I lowered the graphics even though my pc could handle it, but it was maxing my gpu at 99%, I still had this issue. Then the game will just crash and ask to send an error report and you start the loading up process again.

Now onto the actual gameplay... It doesn't feel that bad... I do like running around clearing dungeons get loot and repeat... However the tutorial is shockingly bad, literally doesn't fully explain anything, doesn't point you in any direction, doesn't explain skills or well anything it seems. I may be a bit crazy, maybe I accidently skipped some text, but it is all shoved in the top right corner anyway, with very little direction. I do like that you can just go and do whatever you want really. But when you start to feel weak, which happens fast, you end up grinding the same dungeons for the same loot. Occasionally you may get better  loot but not always. Then there is the systems upon systems of systems of crafting tables... Just spend 10 minutes in the hub and there is like 100 crafting tables to do something, I can't tell you what the game doesn't do a good job of explaining it at all...

All in all I like the little loop of find dungeon, kill, loot and repeat. But it doesn't feel rewarding at all, I would keep playing but when it almost feels like the game is saying STOP! By crashing or saying I have enough power rank for a new area only to die instantly to an enemy, well I say ok I will stop, thank you very much goodbye.

"Trove" feels like a bunch of loose blocks glued together. The game world loads slowly, the frame rate drops, sword swings miss, enemies appear unexpectedly, missions frequently interrupt, movement feels sluggish, the UI fights the player, performance drops during simple actions, and the screen becomes noisy.

Repetition encourages endless grinding, rewards feel empty, classes feel vague, crafting becomes a chore, and the server frequently disconnects.

The first hour is enjoyable, but boredom sets in quickly. The world feels weightless, but combat feels underpowered, and progress stutters.

For a quick bit of fun, sure. For long sessions, skip this game.

Whether you are planning on returning to this game after a break or are looking to get into a quite uniquely-styled voxel game, DON'T play this game in 2025. It has no semblence of what it used to be anymore and there are no redeeming qualities left.

What it has devolved into over the years is a disgustingly monetized snoozefest that is CHOCK FULL with hackers that have absolutely RUINED the games economy over time and are on top of the leaderboards with the most unachievable stats you could imagine. Everyone knows it, no one does a thing. Look up videos about it if you don't believe me.
You will never catch up unless you are prepared to spend literally thousands of dollars on upgrading your gems and mastery points - I am not joking or exaggerating here.

I do sincerely miss the good old Trove I fell in love with years ago but this is now the epitome of pay-to-win, arguably even pay-to-reasonably-progress, and there is a probably just an underpaid skeleton crew left who either can't keep up or don't care about the game enough to make any meaningful changes to its many flawed systems.

I've come back over the years to check on it and can confidently say there is no passion left in this game nor will there ever be again.
It purely exists to milk the player for as much money as they possibly can by making every single system as frustrating and grindy as possible.

I'll probably try to reach 42,5k Power Rank for the most recent highest difficulty just so I can say I REALLY gave it a fair shot and see nothing truly has changed...and then dip again for another 2 years.

Stay the fuck away from this game for your own good. If you want to grind and not get scammed by a greedy publisher and deal with hackers play Warframe instead.

[quote=Trove players] This place is a message… and part of a system of messages… pay attention to it!

Sending this message was important to us. We considered ourselves to be a powerful culture.

This place is not a place of honor… no highly esteemed deed is commemorated here… nothing valued is here.

What is here was dangerous and repulsive to us. This message is a warning about danger.

The danger is in a particular location… it increases toward a center… the center of danger is here… of a particular size and shape, and below us.

The danger is still present, in your time, as it was in ours.

The danger is to the body, and it can kill.

The form of the danger is an evaporation of money.

The danger is unleashed only if you devote time to playing this game. This game is best left shunned and uninhabited. [/quote]

References equating the game to a poisonous nuclear waste dump aside, Trove’s life was a tragic one. 

Trove was born much like its older siblings: full of potential. It had a unique concept, beautiful designs, and entertaining mechanics. It was capable of many things. 

Unfortunately, like its older siblings, Trove was born to two corrupt parents: Trion and Worlds. On the outside, they appeared to be ordinary people, but the Incorporated family was anything but. 

You see, Trion and Worlds were corrupted by the world in which they inhabited. They were obsessed with greed and money, and Trove was the new baby of the family. 

Trove’s experience was not unfamiliar to its older siblings. First, Trove would be fed adequately and had proper attention to ensure it would grow big and strong. The siblings, weak and frail, had no power to avert it other than warning Trove to not fall for it. Alas, Trove continued. 

Trion and Worlds kept giving Trove all the resources it needed: a playerbase, constant updates, and meaningful time. What’s not to love? Maybe Trion and Worlds finally saw that they needed to care for their children in order for them to actually be successful. 

Then, to the surprise of not one of those siblings, the Incorporated parents once again repeated the same pattern: once they thought Trove was grown enough, they paraded it around, slapped stickers and price tags on it, and ignored Trove’s complains of illness and discomfort in order to save money. 

In truth, Trion and Worlds had given Trove the resources it needed to be grown enough, but they had once again planned on wringing as much money out of it as they can. Unfortunately, they also went forward with this plan too soon — Trove was not fully grown to stand on its own, and did not have a sufficient number of players or content to keep them satisfied enough to stay despite shortcomings. The Incorporated parents had overmonetized Trove too early.

This continued for a couple years with Trove slowly starting to become emaciated but glowing with makeup. It was at this time that I, foolishly, became swindled by Trove and spent a lot of time and a bit of money, impressed by Trove’s beauty and satisfied with the gameplay, its content, even its grind. I was oblivious to what was going on under the surface. 

But eventually, I tired of the phase and moved on to other prospects. Shortly after, it was here that a large, scary individual by the name of Gamigo approached the Incorporated parents and said, “I can give Trove better resources and restore it to its former glory. You will have your dream of lavishness and debauchery, for the price of relinquishing ownership of your once-beloved and profitable child.”

Trion and Worlds accepted, and gave the birth certificate to Gamigo so that the god of capitalism could oversee the adoption, sending Trove and all its siblings to the care of Gamigo. 

Four days later, after praying to the god of capitalism, Gamigo lured Trion and Worlds into the rear shipment area and executed both of them with a single gunshot in the head. They were never seen again. Gamigo had full control of Trove and the rest of the Incorporated family. 

Gamigo took full advantage of its new money printers, and took pity on Trove. It looked down and said, “you are unwell and sick. Let me guide you to greatness. Take my hand and follow me to the cafeteria, where my employees shall surely provide you with new content and purpose.” Trove had no choice but to accept. 

The food Trove was forced to eat was the stuff of nightmares. It was, quite literally, a single substance that not only could be redressed to look different on the surface, but it was also a special substance that supplanted some of the unique features that Trion and Worlds both saw on their personal child. This nutritional substance was called Delves, delivered and eaten as Geode, which altered Trove’s appearance and gameplay to be less unique and more trend-chasey, but it remained the same level of uncanny valley that many previous admirers, like myself, became disgusted by. 

Now, Trove’d identity and substance has been supplanted by the slop that Gamigo bestowed upon it. It is no less distasteful and shameful to witness to those who know of Trove’s story, but it is now almost completely devoid of any reference to its parents of Trion and  Worlds Incorporated aside from the most rudimentary mechanics and visual design. Some things, like Shadow Towers, are perhaps left behind by Gamigo — the slop engineered to avoid this particular foreign body — as a semblance of pity upon Trove’s now-dead parents; a symbol of mercy by Gamigo to show that it is not completely enslaved to the god of capitalism because it allowed Trove the privilege of keeping a memento of its past life, despite Trove itself having been grown and developed to have no agency in its life and only born to be the vessel in which its “caregivers” — if they can even be considered giving “care” — channel money through as tribute to the god of capitalism. 

I leave you with this: Trove’s beauty belies a beguiling succubus underneath whose only thoughts are to keep you addicted and to pay tribute. Trove, like its siblings, was born as a means to an end: to serve the greed of Trion and Worlds Incorporated, but it now serves the greed of Gamigo alone. Unfortunately, I am only a fellow human born to likewise be a cog in the machine, and I sometimes find myself unable to deafen my ears to its siren song. You and I must, nonetheless, resist all temptation, without error!
